relation: configure terminal Example: Device# configure terminal
interface type number Example: Device(config)# interface GigabitEthernet 0/0/0
no shut Example: Device(config)# no shut
no ipv6 next-hop-self eigrp as-number Example: Device(config-if)# no ipv6 next-hop-self eigrp 1
Enables privileged EXEC mode. Enter your password if prompted.
Specifies the interface on which EIGRP is configured.
Enables no shut mode so the routing process can start running.
Changes the default IPv6 next-hop value and instructs EIGRP to use the received next-hop value.
pageTitle: IP Routing: EIGRP Configuration Guide, Cisco IOS XE Release 3S (Cisco ASR 1000) - IPv6 Routing: EIGRP Support [Support] - Cisco
textBeforeTable: DETAILED STEPS 11.    show ipv6 eigrp [as-number] interfaces [type number] [as-number] 10.    exit 9.    router-id {ip-address | ipv6-address 8.    ipv6 router eigrp as-number 7.    ipv6 eigrp as-number 6.    ipv6 enable 5.    no shut 4.    interface type number 3.    ipv6 unicast-routing 2.    configure terminal 1.    enable SUMMARY STEPS EIGRP for IPv6 is directly configured on the interfaces over which it runs, which allows EIGRP for IPv6 to be configured without the use of a global IPv6 address. Enabling EIGRP for IPv6 on an Interface Deleting Entries from EIGRP for IPv6 Routing Tables
textAfterTable: Step 6 ipv6 enable Example:  Device(config-if)# ipv6 enable   Enables IPv6 processing on an interface that has not been configured with an explicit IPv6 address.   Step 7 ipv6 eigrp as-number Example:  Device(config-if)# ipv6 eigrp 1   Enables EIGRP for IPv6 on a specified interface.   Step 8 ipv6 router eigrp as-number Example:  Device(config-if)# ipv6 router eigrp 1   Enters router configuration mode and creates an EIGRP IPv6 routing process.   Step 9 router-id {ip-address | ipv6-address Example:  Device(config-router)# router-id 10.1.1.1   Enables the use of a fixed router ID. Use this command only if an IPv4 address is not defined on the router eligible for router ID.
